metadata.case_name: State of Bihar v. Bipat Gope

facts.text: Bipat Gope, resident of Patna district, convicted under s. 323, s. 324 read with s. 511 IPC, sentenced on November 29, 1957 to six months rigorous imprisonment by High Court on appeal against acquittal under s. 417 CrPC.
Not taken into custody till January 6, 1958; kept under armed guard in Patna Medical College Hospital paying ward due to serious illness.
Released by District Magistrate on March 11, 1958 under Jail Manual rules on application by respondent and recommendation of medical authority; unexpired sentence: four months three days.
State contends release under R. 549 (conditional); respondent challenges factum of release under this rule.
Sureties called to produce Bipat Gope; failed; notices issued April 27, 1958 to show cause why surety bonds not forfeited; non-bailable warrant ordered.
Bipat Gope moved petition under Art. 226 on April 29, 1958 against DM order; High Court directed appearance on May 5, 1958.

On May 1, 1958, Bipat Gope appeared before District Magistrate, applied stating filed HC petition, needed to appear there, apprehended maltreatment by police; taken into custody by Senior Deputy Collector, sent to jail.
Earlier HC petition withdrawn on May 2, 1958.
High Court heard petition on May 5, 1958, allowed it after amendments, ordered release; held release by DM unconditional, no rearrest.
Medical certificate by Dr. V.N. Sinha Feb 21, 1958: suffering from disease, not improving.
Civil Surgeon enquiry March 1, 1958; Dr. Sinha March 3: complications sometimes fatal; March 5: in danger of death, likely improve if released.

Jail Superintendent letter to DM with particulars; Judicial Peshkar note: refers Rules 548(1)(2)(3), 549; DM power for sentences <=6 months; unexpired 4m 3d; order: 'Allowed release in the circumstances' dated March 7, 1958.
Release order in Form 105 mentioning Rules 548,549,552 (none scored out); sureties bound to surrender by July 9, 1958.
No return filed by State to HC rule; unclear authority for custody, rearrest by Senior Deputy Collector; non-bailable warrant withdrawn, record to DM who confirmed withdrawal.
State appeal to SC by special leave under Art. 134(1)(c), HC application dismissed.

legal_issues.text: Whether Bipat Gope was released under R. 549 Jail Manual (conditional) or unconditionally, and whether there was lawful authority for his rearrest and detention.
True meaning and extent of Rule 549 Jail Manual.

petitioner_arguments.text: Release of Bipat Gope was under R. 549 Jail Manual (conditional release); sureties failed to produce, bonds forfeitable; rearrest lawful.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: R. 549 Jail Manual Rules under Prisons Act; Form 105

respondent_arguments.text: Release was unconditional; challenges factum of release under R. 549; no lawful authority for rearrest; apprehension of maltreatment.

court_reasoning.text: Record unclear on exact rule of release; neither DM order nor Form 105 specifies R. 549 exclusively; no affidavit/return clarifying rule or authority for rearrest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No lawful authority shown for rearrest; detention illegal.

court_reasoning.text: Quotes Lord Atkin: No executive interference with liberty without supportable legality before court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: British jurisprudence adopted in India; courts must not shrink from deciding.

court_reasoning.text: Proper return with documents essential; absent here, cannot determine facts of rearrest.

holdings.text: In absence of shown lawful authority, rearrest and detention illegal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Eshugbayi Eleko v. The Officer Administering The Government of Nigeria
precedents_cited.relevance: Executive cannot interfere with liberty without legal support before court; applicable to India.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition under Art. 226; special leave appeal.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Habeas corpus proceedings; appeal against acquittal.

statutes_cited.name: Jail Manual
statutes_cited.relevance: Rules for release on medical grounds; conditional or otherwise.

outcome.summary: Appeal by State against High Court order granting habeas corpus and releasing Bipat Gope dismissed; detention held illegal for lack of lawful authority.

key_quotes.text: "In accordance with British jurisprudence no member of the executive can interfere with the liberty or property of a British subject except on the condition that he can support the legality of his action before a Court of justice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes principle against executive overreach on liberty.

key_quotes.text: "It has not been shown in this case that there was any lawful authority under which Bipat Gope was rearrested and in the absence of such lawful authority Bipat Gope's detention cannot be supported and is illegal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on illegality of detention.
